speaker: Elena
text: The article's opening is quite provocative: the West made a 'Faustian bargain' in 1992, believing free markets were inherently superior. And it led us to ruin.

speaker: James
text: Ruin? That's a bit dramatic. We saw unprecedented wealth creation and a global triumph of liberal democracy after the Soviet Union fell.

speaker: Elena
text: But the article argues that wealth was built on a 'faulty lesson.' It claims our historical success wasn't from free markets at all, but from mercantilism.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Ah, mercantilism. Back to the 17th century, are we? I suppose Adam Smith was just a minor distraction then.

speaker: Elena
text: Smith argued against mercantilism, true. But the article says nations like Britain, the US, and Japan *only* became champions of free trade once they were dominant.

speaker: James
text: Go on.

speaker: Elena
text: They built their own industries first, often with high tariffs and protectionist policies. Think of the British Navigation Acts, or the American Morrill Tariff of 1861.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] You're saying they used mercantilism to get rich, then pulled up the ladder?

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly. Once they had a 'comparative advantage in nearly all economic activities,' then they pushed free trade globally to crush competitors. Japan did this post-WWII.

speaker: James
text: Okay, the Japanese example is compelling. They certainly didn't embrace 'shock therapy' in the 1990s.

speaker: Elena
text: No, they protected their nascent industries fiercely. While we were telling former Soviet bloc countries to liberalise 'as fast as possible'.

speaker: James
text: That's a convenient reading of the data. The 1990s were a 'peace dividend' era. Global trade soared, technology boomed. It felt like progress.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] A short-term dividend, perhaps. But the article posits that by 2013, the West appeared 'weaker than at any time since the Ottoman Turks conquered Constantinople in 1453'.

speaker: James
text: That's... actually devastating.

speaker: Elena
text: It implies we learned 'the wrong lesson' about our own historical trajectory. We forgot how we actually rose.

speaker: James
text: [clipped] So the 'triumph of free markets' was a myth, designed to benefit established powers at the expense of emerging ones?

speaker: Elena
text: The article certainly suggests it. It's not that free markets are inherently bad, but that *timing is everything*. You don't open up when you're weak.

speaker: James
text: That's a fair point. But the alternative, pure protectionism, would lead to no trade at all, as Ricardo noted. Globalisation brought immense benefits too.

speaker: Elena
text: Benefits for whom? The article highlights the 'service sector' taking root, especially financial services, promising huge profits 'without the sweat and toil of manufacturing'.

speaker: James
text: Wait, really? That's a direct hit on the post-industrial economy model. We were told that was progress.

speaker: Elena
text: The article connects it to the decline. If you lose your manufacturing base, you lose a fundamental source of wealth creation and employment. We talked about this with 'Robotics and Slavery'.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] Okay, the hollowing out of industrial capacity is a serious concern. We exported those jobs, betting on a financialised future.

speaker: Elena
text: And now we see 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power,' filling the void we left. They certainly aren't following our 'free market' advice.

speaker: James
text: No, China is a master of selective liberalisation. They developed their own industries before opening the gates.

speaker: Elena
text: Which sounds an awful lot like the mercantilist playbook that built Western empires after 1453. The one we supposedly abandoned.

speaker: James
text: [amused] So, we became victims of our own propaganda?

speaker: Elena
text: Perhaps. The article argues the West's 'rise predated Karl Marx by 400 years and its success had nothing to do with free markets'.

speaker: James
text: That's a very uncomfortable truth for many on the centre-right, myself included. It fundamentally challenges the narrative of the last 40 years.

speaker: Elena
text: It means the 'solution' of deregulation and market liberalisation that won the Cold War might have been the very thing that started our decline.

speaker: James
text: A self-inflicted wound. The article's reference to the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center as a pivot point, exposing vulnerability... that's chillingly apt.

speaker: Elena
text: It led us into costly, distracting wars. While the economic core was eroding, we were fighting abroad.

speaker: James
text: And now Europe is rearming, as our other article notes. A continent supposedly beyond large-scale conflict, suddenly spending â‚¬800 billion on defence.

speaker: Elena
text: A clear sign that the 'peace dividend' is well and truly over. And the global balance of power has shifted, just as the article warned it would.

speaker: James
text: So, the Faustian bargain: unparalleled wealth and global dominance for 24 years, from '92 to, say, 2016? And now the devil's collecting?

speaker: Elena
text: The article implies we're in the collection period. The question is, can we still escape it? It does mention an action list, at least.
